I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  On 6 March 2013, the Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) for 
the Public Finance Development Strategy 2020. Dialogue with the Ministry of Finance (MOF) 
clarified the policy and institutional context, and the priorities for ADB support. Agreement was 
reached  with  the  government  on  the  TA’s  impact,  outcome,  output,  implementation 
arrangements,  cost  and  financing  arrangements,  and  terms  of  reference.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. The cost estimates are in Appendix 2 and the terms of 
reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  More  than three  decades  of  successful  reform  have  transformed the  PRC  into the 
world’s second largest economy. Rapid growth allowed for a swift transition from a low-income 
country to a middle-income country. Today, the challenge lies in moving up to high-income 
status and balancing income distribution. In this context, the leadership that took office in March 
2013  has  indicated  their  intention  to  focus  on  the  quality,  efficiency,  and  sustainability  of 
economic growth. The reform priorities to achieve the goal have been identified, and further 
public finance and fiscal reform feature prominently in the new leadership’s reform agenda.  
  
3.  Recent economic trends in the PRC suggest that the high growth rates are stabilizing at 
more moderate levels. This is consistent with government targets for lower growth in the context 
of  economic  restructuring  to  rebalance  the  economy.  Against  this  background,  a  different 
macroeconomic environment will require fiscal policy adjustments including a change in the 
optimal medium-term public revenue share of gross domestic product (GDP), improved tax 
administration, and higher and better targeted social expenditure to increase living standards 
and balance income distribution. 
 
4.  Important public finance system reforms have been implemented in the PRC since 1982 
on  taxation,  budget  management,  and  intergovernmental  fiscal  arrangements.  However, 
systemic  weaknesses  are  reflected  in  large  income  inequality  and  regional  disparities, 
suboptimal  provision  of  basic  social  services,  and  insufficient  fiscal  revenue  to  address 
challenging development needs. This has resulted in a wide income gap and low consumption 
levels constraining the enormous potential of the domestic engines of growth in the PRC.  
  
5.  As economic reforms progressed, state redistributive mechanisms weakened. In the 
1990s,  provision  of  public  services  was  decentralized  to  local  governments,  without  a 
corresponding increase in fiscal transfers. Social spending has increased rapidly since 2008, 
but remains insufficient to ensure optimal delivery of public goods. About 30% of government 
revenue is spent on social security, education, and healthcare, compared with an average of 
52% in other middle-income countries. Moreover, recent reforms have focused on expanding 
the coverage of benefits rather than restructuring the benefits themselves. Universal coverage 
and equal access to social benefits in urban and rural areas requires increased budget support 
and reform of income distribution and equalizing mechanisms. 
 
6.  In the transition to a market-oriented economy, only limited taxation has been introduced. 
Tax revenues in the PRC increased steadily following fiscal reform in 1994 but levels remain low 
at 20% of GDP, compared with the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development

average of 34%. Recent income taxation reforms have reduced the number of personal income 
taxpayers  to  less  than 3%  of the  population, and  yields  amount  to  less  than  6%  of total 
revenue—far below the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development average of 
24%. The narrow income tax base deprives policy makers of a powerful income distribution tool.  
 
7.  Further, revenues are too heavily sourced from indirect taxes (64% of total tax revenue), 
which double desirable levels. Indirect taxes are easy to collect but are regressive, undermining 
efforts to balance income distribution. Greater emphasis on direct taxation would shift the tax 
burden from low-income to high-income households, resulting in a fairer distribution of income. 
From the production point of view, taxes are biased in favor of manufacturing to the detriment of 
the service sector, which is often subject to double taxation under the existing business tax. This 
hampers the development of a sector that is a crucial source of future growth and employment 
generation. 
 
8.  Most importantly, a serious mismatch exists between expenditures and revenues at the 
local government level—resulting from the high degree of expenditure decentralization. The 
central  government  accounts  for  about  30%  of  total  public  expenditure,  whereas  local 
governments assume the remaining 70% with limited resources, as they transfer to the central 
government the largest share of local collections. For instance, 75% of the value-added tax 
(VAT)  revenue,  the  single  largest  source  of  tax  revenue,  is  transferred  to  the  central 
government. Attempts by local governments to address the gap have resulted in an over-
reliance  on  land  sales  and  off-budget  borrowing  through  financing  vehicles,  the  latter 
threatening the stability of the financial sector. 
 
9.  The government has adopted a range of measures to address these challenges. So far, 
they have had limited impact with the low revenue collection, inadequate social expenditure, 
and  a  regressive  bias  in  the  taxation  system.  Recent  pilot  tested  initiatives—such  as  the 
introduction  of  a  property  tax  on  luxury  housing  in  Shanghai  and  Chongqing,  and  the 
replacement of the business tax by the VAT on selected services in 12 cities—are important 
steps in the right direction that need to be developed. 
 
10.  The  scale  of  the  challenges  calls  for  greater  efforts  to  overhaul  public  finance 
management in the PRC. In-depth fiscal and taxation reforms can play a leading role promoting 
a shift toward a more inclusive economic model, as evidenced by successful experiences in 
other countries. In developed economies, large fiscal transfers and reforms to broaden the base 
and increase the progressivity of taxation have proven effective in distributing income. Looking 
forward, reforms should pursue measures to increase the progressivity of taxation to balance 
income  distribution  while  reforming  taxation  to  ensure  optimal  revenue  levels  to  finance 
development challenges. In this context, revenue allocation to the local level needs to be 
aligned  with  expenditure  responsibilities  after  clearly  defining  the  role  of  the  state  in  the 
provision of public finance at all government levels. Otherwise, large disparities in public social 
spending per person will perpetuate inequality.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The impact will be a strengthened fiscal policy and taxation system in the PRC. The 
outcome will be an improved fiscal and taxation framework in the PRC.

3 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The output will be a report containing a strategy to guide public finance reform until 2020 
to promote inclusive growth and more balanced income distribution in the PRC. The report will 
comprise three sub-reports analyzing the priorities of fiscal and taxation reform from different 
angles: (i) the role of the government and public finance and their expected functions to address 
market failures, (ii) taxation and tax administration reform to balance income distribution and 
eliminate tax distortions, and (iii) optimal revenue levels to address development needs amid 
declining growth to ensure an equitable provision of public services.  
  
13.  Sub-report 1 will focus on the role and function of public finance to (i) define the role of 
the government and public finance and their expected functions to address market failures, 
(ii) establish guidelines for well-functioning intergovernmental working arrangements at all levels 
of government, and (iii) optimize public expenditure to ensure efficient and equitable delivery of 
public services.  
 
14.  Sub-report 2 will look into policy actions to reform taxation and tax administration through 
(i) greater taxation progressivity in relation to good international practices to balance income 
distribution, (ii) measures to broaden and simplify the tax structure and adjust tax rates to 
eliminate distortions in the system, and (iii) reforms to address the mismatch in revenue and 
expenditure through increased fiscal transfers and improved tax administration at all levels of 
government. 
 
15.  Sub-report 3 will (i) review and identify weaknesses in revenue collection and sharing to 
reform expenditure assignments; (ii) analyze the fiscal policy implications of slowing economic 
growth to estimate optimal levels of revenue for the sustainable provision of public expenditure, 
in particular on education, health, and social security; and (iii) analyze innovative approaches for 
the effective delivery of public services, including the promotion of various forms of partnerships 
with the private sector. 
 
16.  The three sub-reports will draw on an international study tour. The study tour will focus 
on countries with a high standard of success in the focus area. The study tour will be conducted 
before the preparation of the draft final reform, and the relating output will be incorporated in the 
draft final report. The implementing agency will prepare a short report outlining the contents and 
findings of the study tour. 
 
17.  In addition to the three sub-reports, the final report will include a synopsis containing 
detailed policy recommendations to guide the implementation of the identified reform priorities 
targeting senior policy decision makers in the PRC. 
 
18.  The TA will disseminate research findings and policy recommendations through three 
national workshops (inception, midterm review, and final review), and a final dissemination 
event to present key findings and policy suggestions to a wider audience. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will 
provide in-kind contribution in the form of office space, accommodation, transport, remuneration, 
and per diem of counterpart staff, and other in-kind contribution.

4   
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  The TA will be implemented over 22 months, from 1 August 2013 to 30 June 2015. The 
International  Department  of  the  MOF  will  be  the  executing  agency  for  the  TA.  The 
Comprehensive Department of the MOF will be the implementing agency. The International 
Department  of  the  MOF  will  be  responsible  for  establishing  and  chairing  a  TA  steering 
committee  composed  of  representatives  of  relevant  ministries  and  agencies.  The  steering 
committee will be regularly consulted and invited to participate in TA activities.  
 
21.  In dialogue with the executing agency, ADB will recruit national and international public 
finance experts to provide inputs as individual consultants. A total of 25 person-months of 
individual consulting services (six national consultants for a total of 23 person-months and one 
international  consultant  for  2  person-months)  will  be  selected  based  on  their  academic 
qualifications and relevant work experience. Given the required expertise, the national and 
international  consultants  will  be  selected  and  engaged  on  an  individual  basis  by  ADB  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). The consultant team will be responsible for producing the TA outputs and deliverables in 
a  timely  and  effective  manner,  and  for  organizing  and  carrying  out  all  TA  activities.  The 
consultants will report to the assigned ADB project office, and all outputs and reports will be 
prepared in English. Terms of reference and the required expertise of the consultants are in 
Appendix 3.  
 
22.  The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in accordance with the Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). Equipment procured under the 
TA will be transferred to the executing agency upon TA completion. 
 
23.  TA support for workshops may include costs related to the venue, equipment rental, 
translation, printing and copying, food and beverages, transportation, lodging, logistics and 
administrative support, and other expenditures with prior agreement from ADB. In line with 
standard ADB procedures, the TA will not support the implementing agency’s management fees 
or related costs such as staff salaries and allowances, and the use of implementing agency 
resources (such as office accommodation), which will be provided as part of the counterpart 
contribution.  
 
24.  The executing agency will provide a suitably furnished office with computers, utilities, 
and telecommunications access (including broadband internet connection), materials, maps, 
data, and documents as required under the TA; and will cover the cost of office utilities for the 
consultants. The executing agency will designate a TA focal point with strong English speaking 
and writing skills, and will facilitate all TA activities and links to local government and providers 
to ensure the effective implementation of TA activities.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
25.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for the Public Finance Development Strategy 
2020, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  National Consultants  
1.  Public finance specialist, sub-report 1 leader and team leader (6 person-months, 
intermittent). The specialist will have strong expertise and extensive  experience in diverse 
aspects of fiscal and taxation reform. The specialist must have a master’s degree or higher 
qualification in public finance and related fields, and must be fluent in English. The specialist 
must have at least 15 years of experience in fiscal and taxation reform supported by relevant 
publications and affiliation to a prestigious university or research institute. The specialist will 
(i)  have overall responsibility for the quality and timely delivery of the  technical 
assistance (TA) output, including all sub-reports, and completion of relevant TA 
activities  under  the  guidance  of  the  implementing  agency  and  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) project officer; 
(ii)  prepare an inception report including a review of the weaknesses of the current 
fiscal management and taxation framework to identify critical areas for reform 
under the project, and the specific and more critical issues to be addressed by 
each of the subproject leaders; 
(iii)  adapt  international  experience  lessons  in  fiscal  and  taxation  reform  to  the 
country-specific conditions in the People’s Republic of China (PRC), with support 
from the international consultant; 
(iv)  lead the preparation of sub-report 1: analyzing the role of the government and 
public finance, and their expected functions to address market failures; reviewing 
expenditure  assignments for  all  levels  of government,  in  particular regarding  
education, health, and social security, to assess the optimal expenditure share of 
core public services at all levels of government based on government plans to 
widen access to basic education and medical care; developing intergovernmental 
working  arrangements;  and  drafting  relevant  policy  recommendations  for 
implementation of the proposed reforms; 
(v)  supervise and review the draft and final sub-reports, ensuring that the contents 
address the identified key issues and necessary reforms;  
(vi)  supervise the preparation of the final report by consolidating the sub-reports and 
synopsis into a final volume to be presented in the dissemination event; and 
(vii)  lead  the  preparation  of  workshops  and  conferences  by  drafting  agendas, 
proposing participants and acting as resource person as needed. 
 
2.  Public finance specialists, sub-reports 2 and 3 leaders (two specialists, 8 person-
months total, intermittent). The two national public finance specialists will act as sub-report 
leaders. The specialists will be experienced researchers from reputable universities or research 
institutes with at least 10 years of expertise in public finance in the PRC, supported by a 
relevant university degree. They will work 4 months each, full-time. The specialists must be 
fluent  in  English  and  have  strong  expertise  in  the  areas  of  public  finance,  taxation, 
intergovernmental fiscal relations, public financial management, and associated topics. Each 
specialist will lead the preparation of the assigned sub-report. Because of linkages between 
sub-reports, the two specialists will work in close coordination and under the analytical guidance 
of the team leader, and report to him or her.

B.  International Consultant 
4.  Public finance specialist (2 person-month total, intermittent). The specialist will have 
strong expertise and extensive experience in diverse aspects of taxation reform in different 
countries. The specialist must have a master’s degree or higher qualification in public finance 
and related fields. The specialist must have at least 12 years of experience in fiscal and taxation 
reform  supported  by  relevant  publications  and  professional  experience  or  affiliation  to  a 
prestigious university or research institute. The specialist should have professional experience 
and knowledge of the tax system and public sector management in the PRC. The specialist will 
perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  prepare a report reviewing selected international experiences and practices in 
relevant  fiscal  and  taxation  reforms  to  address  reform  needs  in  the  PRC, 
including tax reform (i.e., VAT, income tax, property tax), expenditure policies, 
and the intergovernmental finance system; 
(ii)  draft relevant policy recommendations;  
(iii)  adapt lessons from successful international experiences in fiscal and taxation 
reform to the country-specific conditions in the PRC; 
(iv)  integrate  the  policy  recommendations  for  implementation  of  the  proposed 
reforms from the international experience perspective with the recommendations 
resulting from the three sub-reports to prepare a policy brief targeting policy 
makers in the PRC to guide implementation of the identified reforms;  
(v)  provide inputs to the team leader for the preparation of inception, midterm, and 
final reports as needed; and 
(vi)  participate in conferences and workshops as resource person as needed.
